Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Residence Location in the Establishment of Community Identity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project addresses the question of how communities adapt to accommodate new migrants. Migration happens at a range of spatial scales, may involve temporary or permanent relocation, occurs in multiple directions, and is undertaken for a variety of reasons that involve pull factors, such as the promise of abundant resources or religious freedom, and push factors, like escaping an oppressive regime or culture of violence. In such contexts, people may choose to flaunt the distinctive and highly visible markers of their identity or opt to mask their identity by emulating or mimicking the material culture of their neighbors, and each strategy has different implications for the successful integration of community members. Many of the less visible attributes of material culture, especially those that are the product of motor skills learned early in life are not easily changed and therefore are strong indicators of cultural origin. Sissel Schroeder will investigate both the high visibility and low visibility attributes of material culture and their spatial distribution at a Mississippian town that formed through population coalescence and rose to prominence in the midcontinent of North America in the 13th century AD, a time of considerable population movement across North America. Gaining insights into how a multi-cultural community forms, is successful for multiple generations, and dissolves has implications for global issues of ethnic unrest in the world today. Undergraduate and graduate students who participate in the project will gain practical hands-on training in archaeological laboratory methods, material culture identification, and curatorial best practices, as well as organizational and analytical skills.

Through the investigation of low visibility attributes, like the directional twist of the fibers used to make cordage and the kinds of clay and temper materials mixed with the clay to make pottery, it will be possible to identify learning communities of people from diverse backgrounds; by also incorporating some high visibility attributes, it will be possible to more fully explore the role of material culture in the constitution and transformation of cultural identity. The research will be conducted on existing archaeological collections that have been curated since the 1940s, thereby enhancing the value of these irreplaceable materials, promoting the importance of archaeological curation, and significantly augmenting basic understanding of the social complexity of an individual community. Dr. Schroeder will apply a novel investigative approach to the study of fabric. Since fabric rarely preserves in the humid Eastern Woodlands, archaeologists are restricted to studying it through impressions left on the exterior of ceramic vessels. Reverse-engineered 3D models developed from high resolution digital photographs of fabric impressions will reveal details of textile production without having to take impressions of the fabric using modern media that contaminate and damage the ancient materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ancient Native Americans did not live in isolation from one another ? the processes of migration, the making of local communities, and their dissolution played out over and over again across the Eastern Woodlands of North America prior to European contact. Because these kinds of developments transcend time and place, the results of this research can contribute to a better understanding of the diverse factors that pull people together or push people to move apart. Material culture and production practices can be distinctive to place of origin, thereby offering a point of entry into investigating population movements, cultural diversity, community formation, and community organization.

This project investigated archaeological material culture, particularly ceramics, fabric impressions on ceramics, perishable architecture, and certain distinctive artifacts, and their spatial distribution within an ancient Mississippian community in western Kentucky that archaeologists call Jonathan Creek. Prior to this project, the prevailing view of the occupation history of Jonathan Creek, based on the analysis of 6% of the ceramic assemblage, was that it had a substantial occupation between AD 1000 and 1150, was deserted for a period of time, and then reoccupied between AD 1300 and 1450. The comprehensive ceramic analysis undertaken for this project, as well as a series of radiocarbon dates, have empirically demonstrated that the primary occupation of the site occurred between AD 1200 and 1300.

This study has shown that the town we call Jonathan Creek formed through population coalescence around AD 1200 and it rapidly grew and rose to regional prominence in the 13th century AD. A Ramey knife (an artifact type associated with Cahokia?s Stirling Phase, c. AD 1100-1200) was found in association with a burial interred early in the occupation history of Jonathan Creek, just before mound construction was initiated. The proportions of different vessel types (jars, pans, bowls, hooded bottles, bottles, seed jars, and plates) at Jonathan Creek are consistent with 13th century ceramic assemblages elsewhere in the region. Thickness:width ratios of jar handles at Jonathan Creek are consistent with 13th and early 14th century assemblages in the region. A small number of shell-tempered cordmarked ceramics, similar to the Cahokia Cordmarked type associated with Moorehead and Sand Prairie phases at Cahokia (c. AD 1200-1350), are present at Jonathan Creek but the chemical composition of the clay used indicates that they were locally made. In addition, unusually large jars similar to ones recovered from 13th century AD sites in southeastern Missouri are found at Jonathan Creek, whereas they are uncommon in other western Kentucky Mississippian assemblages.

Based on the diversity of fabric impressions present on ceramic sherds (66% plain twined, 11% alternate-pair twined, 20% weft-faced), it appears that different communities of practice in textile technology were present at the site. This preliminary analysis of fabric impressions, when compared with analyses of fabric impressions at other sites in the region, shows that Jonathan Creek has a significantly higher percentage of weft-faced fabrics than seen at other sites, indicating that the site had a different composition of learning communities than other sites in the region. Jonathan Creek also has a diversity of architectural types, including wall-trench and single-post foundations, that likely reflects a diversity of people at the site.

Taken together, the material assemblages from Jonathan Creek support the hypothesis that the site was a community in which people from different learning communities rapidly coalesced together beginning around AD 1200 and persisting into the early 14th century AD. Judging from the broad spatial distribution of diverse approaches to fabric production, and varied architectural types, people of different learning communities lived adjacent to one another and were well integrated within village life.

Dissolution and abandonment of the community appears to have occurred relatively rapidly on the cusp of the 14th century. Judging from the spatial distribution of the small number of ceramics that post-date AD 1300, the mounds at the site were in use until abandonment, and evidence for a major conflagration that destroyed the final structure on top of one mound might implicate violence and sociopolitical instability as factors involved in the rapid departure of community members.

In addition to these important findings, this project also developed an innovative, non-destructive, and non-contaminating method called reverse Digital Artifact Imaging (rDAI) that uses Structure from Motion (SfM) photogrammetry to construct 3D digital topographic surface models of the textiles that left impressions on the exterior surface of ceramics associated with the Mississippian archaeological cultural tradition. The project provided formal training and professional development for a half-dozen individuals through instruction in artifact photography, photogrammetry, 3D model development, ceramic analysis, and engagement in research.

Finally, this project demonstrates the importance of curated collections, the wealth of untapped data that lurk within them, and shows that new analyses of old collections can significantly modify our understanding of the ancient occupation and dynamic sociopolitical landscape of a given site.


Last Modified: 04/16/2020
Modified by: Sissel Schroeder

Because these kinds of developments transcend time and place, the results of this research can contribute to a better understanding of the diverse factors that pull people together or push people to move apart. Prior to this project, the prevailing view of the occupation history of Jonathan Creek, based on the analysis of 6% of the ceramic assemblage, was that it had a substantial occupation between AD 1000 and 1150, was deserted for a period of time, and then reoccupied between AD 1300 and 1450. This study has shown that the town we call Jonathan Creek formed through population coalescence around AD 1200 and it rapidly grew and rose to regional prominence in the 13th century AD. AD 1100-1200) was found in association with a burial interred early in the occupation history of Jonathan Creek, just before mound construction was initiated. The project provided formal training and professional development for a half-dozen individuals through instruction in artifact photography, photogrammetry, 3D model development, ceramic analysis, and engagement in research. Finally, this project demonstrates the importance of curated collections, the wealth of untapped data that lurk within them, and shows that new analyses of old collections can significantly modify our understanding of the ancient occupation and dynamic sociopolitical landscape of a given site.
